text:
Dear Fellow Scholars, this is Two Minute Papers
with Károly Zsolnai-Fehér.

Fluid simulation is a mature research field
within computer graphics with amazing papers

that show us how to simulate water flows with
lots of debris, how to perform liquid-fabric
interactions, and more.

This new project further improves the quality
of these works and shows us how thin, elastic

strands interact with oil paint, mud, melted
chocolate, and pasta sauce. There will be

plenty of tasty and messy simulations ahead,
not necessarily in that order, so, make sure
to hold on to your papers, just in case.

Here you see four scenarios of these different
materials dripping off of a thin strand. So,
why are these cases difficult to simulate?

The reason why it’s difficult, if not flat
out impossible because the hair strands and

the fluid layers are so thin, it would require
a simulation grid that is so microscopic,

or in other words, we would have to perform
our computations of quantities like pressure

and velocity on so many grid points, it would
probably take not from hours to days, but

from weeks to years to compute. I will show
you a table in a moment where you will see

that these amazingly detailed simulations
can be done on a grid of surprisingly low
resolution.

As a result, our simulations also needn’t
be so tiny in scale with one hair strand and

a few drops of mud or water. They can be done
on a much larger scale, so we can marvel together

at these tasty and messy simulations, you
decide which is which. I particularly liked

this animation with the oyster sauce because
you can also see a breakdown of the individual

elements of the simulation. Note that all
of the interactions between the noodles, the

sauce, the fork, and plate have to be simulated
with precision. Love it.

And now, the promised table. Here you can
see the delta x that means how fine the grid

resolution is, which is in the order of centimeters,
and not micrometers. That is reassuring, and

don’t forget that this work is an extension
to the Material Point Method, which is a hybrid

simulation method that both uses grids and
particles. And, sure enough, you can see here

that it simulates up to tens of millions of
particles as well, and the fact that the computation

times are still only measured in a few minutes
per frame is absolutely remarkable. Remember,

the fact that we can simulate this at all
is a miracle.

Now, this was run on the processor, and a
potential implementation on the graphics card

could yield us significant speedups, so I
really hope something like this appears in

the near future. Also, make sure to have a
look at the paper itself, which is outrageously

well written. If you wish to see more from
this paper, make sure to follow us on Instagram,

just search for Two Minute Papers there or
click the link in the description.
